July 28, 2013: Fiction
INFERNO, by Dan Brown. (Doubleday.) The symbologist Robert Langdon, on the
run in Florence, must decipher a series of codes created by a Dante-loving
scientist.
HIDDEN ORDER, by Brad Thor. (Emily Bestler/Atria.) As the counterterrorism
operative Scot Harvath searches for the murderer of candidates to head a
powerful, mysterious agency, he uncovers a plot with roots in the 18th century.
AND THE MOUNTAINS ECHOED, by Khaled Hosseini. (Riverhead.) A
multigenerational family saga centers on a brother and sister born in Afghanistan;
from the author of “The Kite Runner.”
THE OCEAN AT THE END OF THE LANE, by Neil Gaiman.
(Morrow/HarperCollins.) A middle-aged man recalls his lonely boyhood and his
friendship with a remarkable girl.
BOMBSHELL, by Catherine Coulter. (Putnam.) After the F.B.I. special agent
Griffin Hammersmith accepts Dillon Savich’s invitation to join him and Lacey
Sherlock, Hammersmith’s sister is savagely beaten.
SECOND HONEYMOON, by James Patterson and Howard Roughan. (Little,
Brown.) As he investigates the murder of a pair of newlyweds, the F.B.I. agent
John O’Hara, last seen in “Honeymoon” (2005), is targeted by a serial killer.
GONE GIRL, by Gillian Flynn. (Crown.) A woman disappears on her fifth
anniversary; is her husband a killer?
BAD MONKEY, by Carl Hiaasen. (Knopf.) A defrocked Miami cop turned
restaurant inspector investigates a grisly murder.
BEAUTIFUL DAY, by Elin Hilderbrand. (Reagan Arthur/Little, Brown.) Various
sorts of disaster threaten a Nantucket wedding.
WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE'S STAR WARS, by Ian Doescher. (Quirk Books.)
Verily, a new hope: The story of a beautiful princess, a hero coming of age, a wise
knight and an evil lord, retold in iambic pentameter.
THE LIGHT IN THE RUINS, by Chris Bohjalian. (Doubleday.) Memories of World
War II are evoked in 1955 when a Florentine police investigator, a former partisan,
tries to find a serial killer who has targeted a Tuscan nobleman’s family.
THE SILVER STAR, by Jeannette Walls. (Scribner.) When their irresponsible
mother takes off, a 12-year-old California girl and her sister join the rest of their
family in Virginia.
THE EYE OF GOD, by James Rollins. (Morrow/HarperCollins.) As the end of the
world looms, Cmdr. Gray Pierce and Sigma Force race to uncover an ancient
Non-Fiction
LEAN IN, by Sheryl Sandberg with Nell Scovell. (Knopf.) The chief operating
officer of Facebook urges women to pursue their careers without ambivalence.
HAPPY, HAPPY, HAPPY, by Phil Robertson with Mark Schlabach. (Howard
Books.) The Duck Commander pays tribute to “faith, family and ducks.”
LET'S EXPLORE DIABETES WITH OWLS, by David Sedaris. (Little, Brown.)
Essays from the humorist on subjects like French dentistry and a North Carolina
Costco.
UNBROKEN, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Random House.) An Olympic runner’s story
of survival as a prisoner of the Japanese in World War II.
I WEAR THE BLACK HAT, by Chuck Klosterman. (Scribner.) Observations on the
modern understanding of villainy.
DAD IS FAT, by Jim Gaffigan. (Crown Archetype.) Life with five kids in a two-
bedroom New York City apartment.
UNBREAKABLE, by Jenni Rivera with Marissa Mateo. (Atria.) A life of the
Mexican-American singer, who was killed in a plane crash in December 2012.
AMERICAN GUN, by Chris Kyle with William Doyle. (Morrow/HarperCollins.) Kyle,
a former member of the Navy SEALs who was shot to death in Texas in February,
tells how 10 firearms changed United States history.
THE DUCK COMMANDER FAMILY, by Willie and Korie Robertson with Mark
Schlabach. (Howard Books.) Behind the scenes at the A&E show “Duck Dynasty.”
ELEVEN RINGS, by Phil Jackson and Hugh Delehanty. (Penguin Press.) An
autobiography by the successful coach, who led his teams to 11 N.B.A.
championships.
THE GUNS AT LAST LIGHT, by Rick Atkinson. (Holt.) The final volume of the
Liberation Trilogy describes the Allied victory in Europe, from D-Day to the
German surrender.
THE BOYS IN THE BOAT, by Daniel James Brown. (Viking.) The University of
Washington’s eight-oar crew and their quest for gold at the 1936 Berlin Olympics.
GETTYSBURG, by Allen C. Guelzo. (Knopf.) A historian’s account of the Civil
War’s most important battle focuses on the experience of ordinary soldiers.
REVOLUTIONARY SUMMER, by Joseph J. Ellis. (Knopf.) This account of the
fateful summer of 1776 weaves the political (Continental Congress) and the
military (Continental Army).
